717815f-a.text:
The Dyckman House, Broadway at the N.W. corner of 204th Street. This house was built early in the eightecuth century, and at the time of this photograph is not quite two hundred years old. The two wings are not a part of the original house, but were added during the 1860's. The house is falling into disrepair through long neglect, but it will soon be restored and converted into a museum, with the surrounding land a city park. The north wing will be demolished, but the south wing will stand as late as 1936, at which
time it will be in use as a caretaker's residence.
1895.
Gift of John H. Judd.

717817f-a.text:
Broadway, at the N. W. corner of Aest 204th Street, showing the old Dyckman House after restoration. IIt was built in the early 1700's and was partially destrbyed by fire by the British in the Revolution. IIt was rebuilt and the family lived here until 1868 when it fell into disrepair. Presented to the City in 1915, it is now a museum.
About 1920
Copyright by
Underwood & Underwood
Gift of Urbrock Collaction

717810f-a.text:
Broadway, at the N. W. corner of West 204th Street, showing the Dvckman farmhouse, built 1787 bv Wm. Dvckman. The original structure (burned bv the British in the Revolutionarr War) was erected by his grandfather, Jan Dvckman, the immigrant, in 1725. The family occupied it until 1868, and presented it to the Citv in 1915. A back porch destroyed inl880 was restored, while the north wing, erected in 1830, was removed. This
is a set of five views taken the same day.
October 1923.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection

1509131-a.title: Broadway - 204th Street, northwest corner

717812f-a.text:
(1)
Broadway, at the N.W. corner of West 204th (Hawthorne) Street. Frame building concerned is the old Dyckman House.
1932.
JJ. Clarence Davies, Collection, Museum of the City of New York.
Negative No. 480.
(2)
A view of the same structure prior to rehabilitation.
1899.
Gift of Randall Comfort.

717814f-a.text:
.oCNhAN HOwS. Broadway and Iast 204th Street, Nanhattan. This is the only reaaining farmhouse of the eighteenf century in Manhattan. iuilt in Jutch Colonial styfa aillaa Jyckman in 1783, it replaced his ear'er house on the same site which was destroyed during the Revolutionary War. In 1915, following restoration of the house and grounds, it was given to the City of New York
by Dyckman's descendants.
Bank ofNew York Calendar 1967-58

717816f-b.text:
(1)
Broadway, at the N. W. corner of West 204th Street, showing the Dyckman
farmhouse, erected in 1787 by Wm. Dyckman.
October, 1923.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection
(2)
The same from another angle, showing in the foreground the 204th Street
side. Broadway, on the extreme right, is not shown.
Summer 1924.

October 1927,
P. L. Sperr.
